title: Analyse Numbers with STL Algorithms
description:
Combine key Standard Library algorithms to sort values and extract insights without manual loops.

Steps:
1. Print `Enter 5 integers:` and read five integers into a `std::vector<int>` in the order received.
2. Use `std::sort` to reorder the numbers ascending, then print `Sorted ascending:` followed by the numbers separated by single spaces (no trailing space).
3. Produce a descending ordering by copying the vector and sorting with `std::greater<int>{}` (or by iterating the ascending vector in reverse) and print `Sorted descending:` with the values.
4. Count how many values are even using `std::count_if` and print `Even count:` with the total.
5. Determine whether every value is positive using `std::all_of`; print `All positive:` followed by `yes` or `no` in lowercase.

Input format:
One line containing five integers separated by spaces.

Expected output:
Enter 5 integers:
Sorted ascending: {ascending}
Sorted descending: {descending}
Even count: {even_count}
All positive: {yes_or_no}

Example run (input `9 3 7 5 1`):
Enter 5 integers:
Sorted ascending: 1 3 5 7 9
Sorted descending: 9 7 5 3 1
Even count: 0
All positive: yes

tests.expected:
Enter 5 integers:
Sorted ascending: 1 3 5 7 9
Sorted descending: 9 7 5 3 1
Even count: 0
All positive: yes

tests.name: analyzes 2 4 6 8 10
tests.expected:
Enter 5 integers:
Sorted ascending: 2 4 6 8 10
Sorted descending: 10 8 6 4 2
Even count: 5
All positive: yes

hints: Store the values in a std::vector<int> numbers(5); then fill using a loop or std::copy_n.
Call std::sort(numbers.begin(), numbers.end()) for ascending order.
Use std::count_if with a lambda n % 2 == 0 and std::all_of with n > 0 to finish the summary.
